title: 107_s550
content: The Act titled "Indian and Alaska Native Foster Care and Adoption Services Amendments of 2001" allows Indian tribes to receive federal funds for foster care and adoption assistance. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act. This includes Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program under specific conditions. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act, including Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program under specific conditions. Indian tribes or consortiums must submit arrangements for payment of funds and child welfare services to the Secretary. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act, including Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program under specific conditions. Indian tribes or consortiums must submit arrangements for payment of funds and child welfare services to the Secretary. SEC. 479B. PROGRAMS OPERATED BY INDIAN TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS. Indian tribes can operate a program under the Social Security Act similar to a State, with modifications to plan requirements including identifying service areas and approving foster homes based on tribal standards for child safety. Indian tribes can approve foster homes based on tribal standards to ensure child safety and accountability, with the federal share determined by the tribe's per capita income. The calculation of an Indian tribe's per capita income is based on the service population defined in its plan. Tribes can submit relevant information for consideration before the Secretary makes the calculation. Administrative expenditures proportions are determined by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary considers per capita income of Indian tribes before making calculations. Proportions for administrative expenditures are determined by the Secretary. Indian tribes can use Federal or State funds to match payments they are eligible for under section 474. The Secretary may modify requirements upon request from Indian tribes. An Indian tribe can use Federal or State funds to match payments under section 474. The Secretary may modify requirements if it benefits the safety of children. Intertribal consortiums can submit a single plan under section 471. An Indian tribe or intertribal consortium can enter into a cooperative agreement with a State for the administration or payment of funds under this part. Any provisions incorporated in the agreement shall be valid and enforceable, with the agreement remaining in effect unless revoked or modified by either party. The cooperative agreement between an Indian tribe or intertribal consortium and a State for fund administration is valid and enforceable. The agreement can be revoked or modified by either party. The Secretary must promulgate regulations within a year in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations. The definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The amendments made by this section take effect. The amendments made by this section take effect on the date of enactment of this Act without regard to regulations.
